questions.question: A 62-year-old female with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents to the emergency department with new-onset chest pain and fatigue. An electrocardiogram shows ST-segment changes suggestive of ischemia. Which scan type should be prioritized in this case?

options.A: Thallium scan
options.B: Pyrophosphate scan

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Thallium scan Explanation: This scan specifically evaluates areas of decreased blood flow, making it the most suitable choice given the patient's symptoms and EKG findings suggestive of ischemia. Purpose Scan types For Myocardial Perfusion Assess ischemia Cold spot: decreased uptake in ischemic areas. Thallium scan (Commonly used) Tetrofosmin Sestamibi scan. For Myocardial Infarction (Option B ruled out) Assess infarct Hot spot in infarct area as pyrophosphate accumulates and is not metabolized. 99m Tc - Pyrophosphate scan. For Ventricular Function (Option C ruled out) Evaluate ejection fraction MUGA (Multiple Gated Acquisition) scan (AKA nuclear ventriculography) Radiolabeled RBCs are used Most accurate for ventricular function - Cardiac MRI For Myocardial Viability (Option D ruled out) Assess the viability of myocardium PETscan - Best investigation for myocardial viability. Perfusion and metabolism mismatch are observed in the PET scan. Perfusion Agents :N-13 ammonia and Rubidium chloride. Metabolism Agent : FDG-PET is used for glucose metabolism. No FDG uptake indicates a normal heart or an infarct. FDG uptake is present: In the Ischemic Myocardium FDG-PET is combined with perfusion imaging for comprehensive assessment. Uptake in PET with low perfusion indicates reversible dysfunction (suggestive of hibernation ). Irreversible dysfunction indicates the presence of scar tissue . Note: Hibernating myocardium is ischemic but viable.

questions.question: A 65-year-old patient with a history of smoking undergoes a positron emission tomography (PET) scan for suspected lung cancer. The scan shows increased radiotracer uptake in the right lung. However, further investigation reveals no malignancy. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this false positive result?

options.A: Low metabolic activity of the tumor
options.B: Physiological uptake due to muscle activity
options.D: Inflammation from a recent pneumonia infection

questions.explanation: such as pneumonia, can lead to increased uptake of the radiotracer in PET scans, mimicking cancerous activity. This is a common cause of false positive results, where the scan suggests malignancy when there is none. Challenges in PET Scans False Positive Results Definition : Indication of cancer activity when there is none. Common Causes : Cause Description Inflammation and Infection Conditions like pneumonia, sarcoidosis, and infections (e.g., tuberculosis) cause increased FDG uptake. Post-Surgical Changes Inflammatory responses post-surgery may yield false positives if scans are done too soon. Benign Tumors High FDG uptake can occur in benign lesions like granulomas or abscesses. Physiological Uptake Normal activities (muscle use, brown fat metabolism) may mimic malignancy. (Option B ruled out) False Negative Results Definition : Failure to detect existing cancer. Common Causes : Cause Description Low Metabolic Activity Tumors Cancers like bronchioalveolar carcinoma may show minimal FDG uptake. (Option A ruled out) Small Tumors Tumors smaller than detection thresholds may be missed. (Option C ruled out) Timing of Scans Timing relative to treatment affects uptake; treated tumors may show reduced FDG levels despite viable cancer. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9983352/

questions.question: A 55-year-old male patient diagnosed with nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) is being considered for radiotherapy. Which of the following statements regarding the radiosensitivity of NPC is correct?

options.A: Low radiosensitivity, high failure rates.
options.B: Highly radiosensitive; 70% to 98% control with IMRT.

questions.explanation: highly radiosensitive, with locoregional control rates of 70% to 98% when treated with intensity-modulated radiotherapy (IMRT). Radiosensitive Tumors Definition : Tumors that respond well to radiation, leading to significant shrinkage or eradication. Examples : Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma (NPC) : Highly radiosensitive; 70–98% control rates with IMRT. (Option A ruled out) Chemotherapy enhances outcomes. HPV-positive Oropharyngeal Carcinoma : Excellent cure rates post-radiotherapy. Mechanisms : Immune Activation : High levels of CD8+ T cell infiltration increase radiation response. Gene Profiles : Radiosensitive tumors exhibit favorable gene expression for radiation efficacy. Radioresistant Tumors Definition : Tumors with low response to radiation, often leading to recurrence or treatment failure. Examples : Subtypes of Breast Cancer & Glioblastomas : Challenging to treat with radiotherapy. NPC (Subset) : Some cases show resistance due to molecular factors. Mechanisms : Gene Expression : High levels of RPA1 linked to poor survival after radiotherapy in NPC. (Option D ruled out) Epithelial-Mesenchymal Transition (EMT) : Promotes resistance by increasing invasiveness. (Option C ruled out) Biomarkers & Targeted Strategies : Biomarkers (e.g., MLKL pathway) guide therapy and improve sensitivity in resistant tumors. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9250625/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7661868/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5822441/

questions.explanation: γ -H2AX foci indicating unrepaired DNA damage γ -H2AX foci indicating unrepaired DNA damage Explanation: High levels of γ -H2AX foci suggest inefficient DNA repair mechanisms, which is associated with increased radiosensitivity, as the cells struggle to repair radiation-induced damage. Intrinsic Radiosensitivity: Sensitive vs. Resistant Tumors Intrinsic radiosensitivity refers to a tumor's natural ability to respond to radiation, which varies between and within tumors. This variability impacts the effectiveness of radiotherapy. Key Insights on Radiosensitivity Tumor Type Variations Radiosensitivity differs widely across tumor types and even among the same tumor cells. A study on 27 canine cancer cell lines showed survival fractions (SF2) ranging from 0.19 to 0.93, indicating that factors beyond tumor type, like cellular traits, influence radiosensitivity. Cellular Factors Influencing Radiosensitivity DNA Repair Efficiency Tumors with poor DNA double-strand break (DSB) repair mechanisms, indicated by high residual γ -H2AX foci, are more radiosensitive. (Option A ruled out) Apoptosis Rates Tumors with higher rates of apoptosis (e.g., lymphoid tumors) respond better to radiation. (Option B ruled out) Tumor Microenvironment Tumors with lower radiosensitivity scores often have higher immune activation, suggesting a more immune-active environment can improve radiation response. Intra-Tumor Heterogeneity Different cell types within a tumor show varying radiosensitivity, with cancer stem cells (CSCs) being more resistant (Option D ruled out) , compared to ordinary cancer cells (OCCs), leading to recurrence after radiotherapy. Treatment Implications Personalized Radiotherapy Assessing a tumor's radiosensitivity helps tailor radiation doses and schedules, optimizing treatment outcomes. questions.question: A 55-year-old male is undergoing fractionated radiotherapy for the treatment of a large head and neck tumor. The radiation oncologist opts for a standard fractionation schedule. Which of the following principles is not part of the "5 Rs of Radiobiology" that underlie the rationale for fractionation?

options.A: Radiosensitivity
options.B: Repair

questions.explanation: Instead, radioresistance generally refers to the inherent resistance of certain tumor cells to the effects of radiation, which is not a principle underlying fractionation. Fractionated Radiotherapy Definition : Treatment in multiple smaller doses (fractions) to enhance tumor control and protect normal tissue. Key Principles Therapeutic Window : Balances damage to tumor vs. normal tissue using the "5 Rs of Radiobiology": Radiosensitivity : Tumor cells are more sensitive to radiation. (Option A ruled out) Repair : Normal tissue repairs better between treatments. (Option B ruled out) Reoxygenation : Hypoxic tumor cells reoxygenate, increasing sensitivity. (Option D ruled out) Redistribution : Cells cycle through phases of varying sensitivity. Repopulation : Normal tissue regeneration, affecting treatment outcomes. Fraction Size and Dose : Standard doses are 1.8-2 Gy per session, totaling 50-66 Gy over weeks. Advances in Fractionation Technique Key Features Spatially Fractionated Radiation Therapy (SFRT) Delivers heterogeneous doses to spare normal tissue, effective in bulky tumors. Hyperfractionation More frequent, smaller doses to enhance local control. Accelerated Fractionation Shortens overall treatment time, maintaining or enhancing efficacy. Challenges Radioresistance : Tumors may develop resistance, requiring careful dose planning. Scheduling : Ideal fractionation depends on tumor type, size, and location; research is ongoing radiotherapy algorithm" data-author="" data-hash="8211" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/gckvXwSqIcNG5gENcjB11744100465.png" /> fractionation patterns" data-author="" data-hash="8212" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/jBc50eJRLrf7ivoEgqfB1744100485.png" /> Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10684810/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8836217/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7041652/

questions.question: A 9-year-old patient is undergoing proton therapy for a localized brain tumor located near critical structures like the optic nerve and brainstem. The radiation oncologist uses proton therapy to take advantage of the Bragg peak. What is the primary benefit of using proton therapy with the Bragg peak in this scenario?

options.A: Uniform radiation delivery to both the tumor and surrounding brain tissues.
options.B: Deliver the highest dose of radiation at the tumor site while sparing the optic nerve and brainstem.
options.C: Greater radiation scatter, which is ideal for treating tumors near critical structures.
options.D: Photon therapy provides better tissue sparing than proton therapy.

questions.explanation: nerve and brainstem. brainstem. Explanation: The Bragg peak is a distinctive property of protons that allows them to deposit most of their energy directly at the tumor site and significantly less radiation to the surrounding critical structures like the optic nerve and brainstem. Protons slow down faster as they travel through tissues and release more energy as they decelerate, culminating in the Bragg peak . Bragg peak: It is a distinct property of protons that describes the point at which a proton beam deposits the maximum amount of energy. Protons, unlike x-rays, slow down faster as they travel through tissues and release more energy as they decelerate, culminating in the Bragg peak. This peak allows the majority of radiation to be focused on the target with minimal scatter to surrounding tissues. (Option A & C ruled out) The proton beam can be shaped to match the tumor, delivering most radiation to the tumor while sparing nearby normal tissues. questions.question: Which of the following best describes the Warburg effect in cancer cells?

options.A: Cancer cells prefer oxidative phosphorylation under anaerobic conditions
options.B: Tumor cells primarily use glycolysis even in the presence of oxygen
options.C: Lactate production occurs only under hypoxic conditions in tumors
options.D: Mitochondrial function is absent in cancer cells

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Tumor cells primarily use glycolysis even in the presence of oxygen. supporting rapid proliferation. This results in increased glucose uptake and lactate production , a hallmark of many tumors. Warburg Effect Cancer cells prefer glycolysis over oxidative phosphorylation, even in the presence of oxygen. This leads to increased glucose uptake and lactate production , common in many cancers. 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (18F-FDG) , a glucose analog used in PET imaging, helps study this effect. Mechanisms of 18F-FDG Accumulation Mechanism Description Aerobic Glycolysis Cancer cells rely heavily on glycolysis, increasing glucose and 18F-FDG uptake, even with oxygen. Transport & Trapping GLUT-1 transporters mediate glucose entry. 18F-FDG is phosphorylated and trapped inside cells. Tumor Heterogeneity Differences in tumor subtype, size, and microvasculature affect 18F-FDG uptake. Clinical Implications of 18F-FDG Implication Details Prognostic Indicator Higher 18F-FDG uptake correlates with worse prognosis (e.g., shorter DFS in invasive ductal carcinoma). Reverse Warburg Effect Cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) increase glycolysis in tumor cells via metabolic coupling. Treatment Monitoring PET imaging tracks changes in 18F-FDG uptake, reflecting therapy responses targeting glycolysis or mitochondria. Cancer cells prefer oxidative phosphorylation under anaerobic conditions (Option A): Oxidative phosphorylation is suppressed, not preferred, in cancer cells. Lactate production occurs only under hypoxic conditions in tumors (Option C): Lactate is produced even in oxygen-rich environments, not just under hypoxia. Mitochondrial function is absent in cancer cells (Option D): Mitochondrial function is reduced but not completely absent. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6898688/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2481565/

questions.question: A 6-year-old patient is referred for a renal scan to assess for potential scarring or morphological changes in the kidneys due to a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. Which of the following scans would be the most appropriate for evaluating the kidneys in this scenario?

options.A: DTPA Scan
options.B: MAG3 Scan

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) DMSA Scan Explanation: It is specifically designed to assess renal morphology and can identify structural abnormalities such as scarring, ectopic kidneys, and damage from conditions like vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). It provides a static image of the kidneys, making it particularly useful for evaluating potential damage related to recurrent urinary tract infections. Renal Scan Purpose Type Key Points DMSA Assess scar or morphological changes in kidneys (e.g., VUR) Morphological/Static Scintigraphy Identifies abnormalities (e.g., ectopic kidney) IOC for VUR is VCUG/MCU DTPA (Option A) Assess kidney function (GFR) Dynamic Scintigraphy Estimates GFR Excreted by glomerular filtration, not tubular secretion MAG3 (Option B) Evaluate overall renal function Dynamic Scintigraphy Assesses GFR and tubular function Diuretic Renography Assess obstruction in pelvi-ureteric junction Dynamic Scintigraphy Rule in/out PUJ obstruction in hydronephrosis without hydroureter Captopril DTPA (Option D) Evaluate renal artery stenosis and other renovascular diseases. Dynamic Scintigraphy A significant GFR decrease indicates RAAS dependence Contraindicated in renal artery stenosis Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK562236/

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a 12-hour history of severe right upper quadrant pain. A scan is performed after the injection of a radiopharmaceutical as shown below. Which of the following findings is not consistent with the image shown?

options.A: Cystic duct obstruction
options.B: Prompt excretion into the bile ducts
options.C: Tracer activity was seen in the gallbladder

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Cystic duct obstruction Explanation: The given image shows a normal Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid scan (HIDA scan) A normal HIDA scan indicates that there is no obstruction. If the cystic duct were obstructed, the gallbladder would not be visualized. HIDA scan and acute cholecystits" data-author="NA" data-hash="8153" data-license="NA" data-source="https://www.prepladder.com/neet-ss-surger y/git-hepatobiliary-and-pancreatic-surgery/biliary-tree-pathophysiology-investigations" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/0GCUprzuhuD1utVldKFV1744091614.png" /> Scintigraphy principle: 1. Radiopharmaceutical Injection A radioactive tracer (e.g. iminodiacetic acid) is injected through IV. This tracer is taken up by the liver and biliary tract. 2. Gamma Ray Detection As the tracer moves from the liver to the gallbladder and then to the duodenum, it emits gamma rays, which are detected by a gamma camera. 3. Image Creation The gamma camera is moved over the abdomen to capture images, allowing visualization of the liver, gallbladder, and biliary tract, revealing their structure and function. Prompt excretion into the bile ducts (Option B) : This finding is consistent with a normal scan. Tracer activity was seen in the gallbladder (Option C) : This finding aligns with a normal HIDA scan, where the tracer is taken up by the gallbladder. Radioisotope used is 99mTc (Option D) : This is accurate and consistent, as technetium-99m is the standard radioisotope used in HIDA scans.
